{{Infobox scholar | image = Paul Zarifopol.gif | alt = | caption = Zarifopol as an ''Institutele-Unite'' student, 1891 | name = Paul Zarifopol | fullname = | other_names = Anton Gherman, Z. | birth_date = {{birth date|1874|11|30}} | birth_place = [[Iași]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1934|5|1|1874|11|30}} | death_place = [[Bucharest]] | era = 20th century | region = [[Eastern Europe]] | school_tradition = {{hlist|[[Rationalism]]|[[Neo-Kantianism]]|[[Aestheticism]]}} | main_interests = [[sociology of literature]], [[aesthetics]], [[philology]], [[poetics]], [[Romanian literature]], [[medieval literature]], [[Phenomenology (philosophy)|phenomenology]], [[social criticism]] | notable_ideas = | major_works = | influences = [[Nikolai Berdyaev]], [[Henri Brémond]], [[Ion Luca Caragiale]], [[Titu Maiorescu]], [[Stéphane Mallarmé]], [[Alois Riehl]], [[Paul Valéry]] | influenced = [[Mihail Sebastian]] }} '''Paul Zarifopol''' (November 30, 1874 – May 1, 1934) was a [[Romania]]n literary and social critic, essayist, and literary historian. The scion of an aristocratic family, formally trained in both philology and the [[sociology of literature]], he emerged in the 1910s as a rebel, highly distinctive, voice among the Romanian press and book reviewers. He was a confidant and publisher of the Romanian writer [[Ion Luca Caragiale]], building his theories on Caragiale's already trenchant appraisals of Romanian society and culture. Zarifopol defended [[art for art's sake]] even against the [[Marxism]] of his father-in-law, [[Constantin Dobrogeanu-Gherea]], and the [[Poporanism]] of his friend, [[Garabet Ibrăileanu]]. He was also a noted censurer of [[Neoclassicism|neoclassical]] trends, of [[philistinism]], and of inauthentic customs, advocating renewal, but not revolution. A skeptic reviewer of [[modernist literature]], he reemerged during the interwar as its dedicated promoter, but his preference for literary entertainment over substance and many of his literary bets were shortly dismissed by other experts of the day.
Zarifopol endures in cultural memory as an eccentric—not just because he tackled and derided the literary establishment, but also because he refused to publish most of his work in book form, or take up employment in academia. Having lost a considerable fortune, he lived withdrawn from the public eye, surviving on his revenues as a literary columnist, mostly for Ibrăileanu's ''[[Viața Românească]]''. Shortly before his death, he set up his own successful magazine, ''[[Revista Fundațiilor Regale]]''. In such venues, Zarifopol defended his cosmopolitan philosophy against other philologists, but also against the emerging neotraditionalists at ''[[Gândirea]]'' journal. Zarifopol viewed modern traditionalism as a fabrication and, with his essays, came out as a non-traditionalist and anti-[[Totalitarianism|totalitarian]] conservative thinker.
==Biography== ===Origins and early life=== The future critic was born in [[Iași]] to Paul (Pavel) Zarifopol, or "Zarifopoulo", and his wife Elena (''née'' Culiano). His paternal family had attested [[Greeks in Romania|Greek]],<ref name="izjnote">"Biographical Note", in Ilinca Zarifopol-Johnston, ''Searching For Cioran'', p. 271. Bloomington: [[Indiana University Press]], 2009. {{ISBN|978-0-253-35267-5}}</ref> and more generically "southern" or [[Balkans|Balkan]],<ref name="evmicle">{{ro icon}} Elena Vulcănescu, [http://convorbiri-literare.dntis.ro/VULCANESCUsep10.html "Veronica Micle era bunică. Documente și corespondență inedite"], in ''[[Convorbiri Literare]]'', September 2010</ref><ref>[[Mircea Muthu]], "Discussions. Sur le roman historique balkanique et sud-est européen", in ''Revue Des Études Sud-est Européennes'', Nr. 1/1977, p. 165</ref> roots. Originally horse traders and assignees for [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman Turks]] settled in [[Moldavia]], they were elevated into the [[Boyars of Wallachia and Moldavia|Moldavian boyar nobility]] after 1850.<ref name="izjnote"/>
On his mother's Culiano side, Paul was related to prestigious literary and political figures. One of Elena's brothers<ref name="evmicle"/> was [[Nicolae Culianu]], the boyar, astronomer, and doyen of ''[[Junimea]]'' literary society, great-grandfather of the religious scholar-novelist [[Ioan Petru Culianu]].<ref>Ted Anton, ''Eros, Magic, & the Murder of Professor Culianu'', pp. 31–32, 233. Evanston: [[Northwestern University Press]], 1996. {{ISBN|0-8101-1396-1}}</ref> His other maternal uncle, who remained closest to Elena, was jurist Ștefan "Nei" Stamatiu-Culianu, also a ''Junimea'' man. A sister of theirs, Maria Nanu, was the wife of landowner Gheorghe Nanu—making Paul Jr a first cousin of poet [[D. Nanu]].<ref name="evmicle"/>
The elder Zarifopol managed the estates of [[List of rulers of Moldavia|Moldavian Prince]] [[Mihail Sturdza]] in [[Cristești, Iași|Cristești]]. It was there that he and Elena met. According to scholar Elena Vulcănescu, it is possible that Paul Jr was not his natural son, but born to Elena from a liaison with General [[Grigore Sturdza]], heir to the Sturdza estate.<ref name="evmicle"/> Zarifopol eventually bought for himself the [[Baroque architecture|baroque]] manor and Sturdza property at [[Filipești|Cârligi]], near [[Roman, Romania|Roman]], then a townhouse in Iași, where he and Stamatiu-Culianu managed Borta Rece tavern.<ref name="evststam">{{ro icon}} Elena Vulcănescu, [http://convorbiri-literare.dntis.ro/VULCANESCUmar12.htm "La un portret inedit al junimistului Ștefan Stamatiu-Culianu zis Nei"], in ''[[Convorbiri Literare]]'', March 2012</ref> His brothers George and Ștefan Zarifopol both had careers in local politics—the former, a Paris-trained agronomist,<ref name="evmicle"/> as a [[Prefect (Romania)|Prefect]], the latter as a delegate to [[Chamber of Deputies of Romania|Chamber]].<ref name="evststam"/> Paul Sr was the great-uncle of poet [[Dimitrie Anghel]];<ref name="evmicle"/> another of his nephews, Alexandru Zarifopol, was the adoptive father of writer [[Alexandru Paleologu]].<ref>{{ro icon}} Tudorel Urian, [http://www.romlit.ro/familia_paleologu_ipoteze_legende_fantezii_ii "Familia Paleologu: ipoteze, legende, fantezii (II)"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 45/2009</ref>
Paul Sr died in 1881,<ref>Săndulescu, p. 408</ref> leaving Stamatiu in charge of family affairs.<ref name="evststam"/> Their family fortune helped finance both sides of the family, and the Culianu children were all educated abroad.<ref name="evmicle"/> Paul Jr himself graduated from ''Junimea''{{'}}s ''Institutele-Unite'' private high school,<ref>Călinescu, p. 910</ref> followed by the literature faculty of [[Iași University]], from 1892 to 1898.<ref name="sasu">[[Mircea Muthu]], "Zarifopol Paul", in Aurel Sasu (ed.), ''Dicționarul biografic al literaturii române'', Vol. II, pp. 868–869. Pitești: [[Editura Paralela 45]], 2004. {{ISBN|973-697-758-7}}</ref> He made his published debut in [[Alexandru Dimitrie Xenopol]]'s ''Arhiva'' in 1897, with a review of a historiographical work by [[Marie Henri d'Arbois de Jubainville]].<ref name="sasu"/><ref>Rodica Florea, "Reviste și scriitori în ultimele două decenii ale secolului al XIX-lea", in [[Șerban Cioculescu]], [[Ovidiu Papadima]], [[Alexandru Piru]] (eds.), ''Istoria literaturii române. III: Epoca marilor clasici'', p. 975. Bucharest: [[Editura Academiei]], 1973.</ref> In 1899, he wrote a short story, ''Povestea Moșului'' ("The Tale of the Old Man"). Well-liked by his literary friends [[Gheorghe T. Kirileanu]] and [[Paul Bujor]], it was published in ''Carmen Sylva'' magazine under the pen name of "Z.".<ref>Cristina Bădară, "G. T. Kirileanu în colecțiile Bibliotecii Centrale Universitare Carol I", in ''Revista Bibliotecii Naționale a României'', Nr. 2/2006, pp. 46, 50</ref>
In 1902, Zarifopol's professor, [[Alexandru Philippide]], took him on as an assistant and considered him for a likely successor; Zarifopol excused himself, and recommended the [[History of the Jews in Romania|Jewish]] intellectual [[Heimann Hariton Tiktin]] for that position. As he noted, Tiktin was more qualified, despite being targeted by a "rather violent antisemitic current".<ref>Lucian Nastasă, ''Antisemitismul universitar în România (1919-1939)'', pp. 47–48. Cluj-Napoca: Editura Institutului pentru Studierea Problemelor Minorităților Naționale, 2011, {{ISBN|978-6-06-927445-3}}</ref> Instead, Zarifopol left for [[German Empire|Germany]] to specialize in philology (under [[Hermann Suchier]]),<ref name="ln(10)295">Nastasă (2010), p. 295</ref> and philosophy, as a student of [[Alois Riehl]]'s [[Objectivity (philosophy)|objectivist worldview]].<ref>Florian, p. 171</ref> He took a doctorate at the [[Martin Luther University of Halle-Wittenberg|University of Halle]] in 1904, with a dissertation on [[trouvère]] [[Richard de Fournival]].<ref name="sasu"/>
===Caragiale companion=== On April 25, 1903,<ref name="evmicle"/> at Berlin, Zarifopol married Ștefania (Fany) Dobrogeanu-Gherea, the daughter of [[Constantin Dobrogeanu-Gherea]]. Zarifopol was an atheist;<ref name="esstein">[[Eugen Simion]], "Nicolae Steinhardt", in ''Caiete Critice'', Nr. 1–2/2007, p. 10</ref> Fany was Jewish, and, like Zarifopol, a religious nonconformist. The couple turned up at the marriage registrar in street clothes and neither held a church wedding nor baptized their children; all this outraged his mother, a strict [[Romanian Orthodox]].<ref name="s407">Săndulescu, p. 407</ref> Dobrogeanu-Gherea, a literary critic, and his son [[Alexandru Dobrogeanu-Gherea|Alexandru]] were also [[Marxism|Marxist]] doctrinaires; Alexandru's daughter, also called Fany, was married to [[Ion Luca Caragiale]]'s son [[Luca Caragiale|Luca (Luki)]].<ref>Călinescu, pp. 710, 1017</ref> While visiting his in-laws, Zarifopol met various figures of international socialism, including revolutionist [[Karl Radek]].<ref name="vtstilist">{{ro icon}} [[Vladimir Tismăneanu]], [http://www.lapunkt.ro/2014/07/21/un-stilist-al-ideilor-paul-zarifopol-si-snobismul-mesianic/ "Un stilist al ideilor: Paul Zarifopol și snobismul mesianic"], in ''LaPunkt'', July 21, 2014</ref>
The Zarifopols had two children: daughter Sonia (born 1904), and son Paul (born 1905).<ref name="s407"/> Selling their Cârligi home in 1906,<ref name="evststam"/> the new family settled in [[Leipzig]], where Paul developed a friendship with Caragiale the elder, who frequently visited from Berlin; with [[Dimitrie Gusti]] and [[Panait Cerna]], he is described by Caragiale biographers as the comedic writer's closest Romanian friends in old age,<ref>Călinescu, p. 495; Iosifescu, p. 319</ref> or even, with an affinity in "sneering spirits", as his one true friend.<ref>Constantinescu, p. 278</ref> The relationship proved decisive in Zarifopol's evolution as a critic, but also left a trace on Caragiale's style: Zarifopol introduced him to the work of [[Anatole France]].<ref>Iosifescu, p. 342</ref> Until Caragiale's death in 1912, he and Zarifopol pursued a steady correspondence. Sometimes involving [[kitsch]] postcards they each collected for their involuntary humor,<ref>[[Ștefan Cazimir]], ''Caragiale față cu kitschul''. Bucharest: [[Cartea Românească]], 1988, p. 103. {{OCLC|21523836}}</ref> such exchanges were noted for witticisms and ridicule of traditional writers. They also shed light on Caragiale's intellectual, psychological, and artistic evolution, making Zarifopol a prime reference in that field.<ref>Iosifescu, pp. 322, 326, 327–329, 339, 344, 345, 351, 352, 355, 358</ref>
[[File:Fam. Zarifopol, Ghermani, Gherea (Sinaia 1908).jpg|thumb|300px|[[Constantin Dobrogeanu-Gherea]], Dionisie Ghermani Sr, and Zarifopol (top row, from the right), vacationing in [[Sinaia]] in 1908. Fany and Sonia Zarifopol are kneeling to Zarifopol's left; Paul the younger is front row, held in her arms by pianist [[Maria Cernovodeanu]]]] From 1908 to 1911, Zarifopol contributed to the [[Munich]]-based ''[[Süddeutsche Monatshefte]]''.<ref name="sasu"/> Also a correspondent for the Romanian literary press, his writing broke with the older canons of Romanian literary criticism and brought him to the attention of Dobrogeanu-Gherea disciple [[Garabet Ibrăileanu]].<ref name="ln(10)295"/> Co-opted by the latter to write for ''[[Viața Românească]]'', Zarifopol made himself known for sarcastic comments about [[modernist literature]], describing [[Marcel Proust|Proust]], [[André Gide|Gide]], and [[Jean Cocteau|Cocteau]] as difficult "boys and children".<ref>Iorga, p. 314</ref> Instead, he persuaded Ibrăileanu to publish there a novel written in collaborations by two of his brothers-in-law, Luki and [[Ionel Gherea]].<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Ioana Pârvulescu]], [http://www.romlit.ro/n_numele_fiului "În numele fiului"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 10/2001</ref> Together with the latter, he also supervised the debut of a female novelist, [[Lucia Demetrius]].<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Lucia Demetrius]], [http://www.romlit.ro/memorii "Memorii"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 4/2004</ref>
In 1915, Zarifopol and his family returned to Romania.<ref name="sasu"/> By then, World War I had broken out, with Romania settled in uneasy neutrality [[Treaty of Bucharest (1916)|until 1916]]. For much of that interval, Zarifopol was a literary contributor for [[Tudor Arghezi]]'s ''Cronica'', but did not necessarily share the magazine's radical stances, nor its anti-war "[[Germanophilia]]".<ref>[[Lucian Boia]], ''"Germanofilii". Elita intelectuală românească în anii Primului Război Mondial'', p. 103. Bucharest: [[Humanitas publishing house|Humanitas]], 2010. {{ISBN|978-973-50-2635-6}}; Iorga, p. 212</ref> During the [[Romania in World War I|campaigns of 1916–1917]], Zarifopol and his family remained in Iași; all of southern Romania fell to the Germans. For a while, accepting Ibrăileanu's offer, he returned to his alma mater as a substitute professor, replacing C. Fedeleș (presumed missing in action). Upon Fedeleș's unexpected return, Zarifopol was sacked.<ref>Nastasă (2010), pp. 295–296</ref> In late 1916, the family took refuge in [[Russian Empire|Russia]], settling for a while in Moscow, but were driven out by the [[October Revolution]].<ref name="evmicle"/>
===Interwar losses and recovery=== Described by historian Lucian Nastasă as a withdrawn, "[[Neurasthenia|neurasthenic]]" and "very impractical" person,<ref name="ln(10)296">Nastasă (2010), p. 296</ref> Zarifopol was financially ruined in the monetary devaluation that took place after the war.<ref name="evmicle"/><ref name="sasu"/> He supported himself by turning to regular journalism, but still had trouble making ends meet (though he did not admit to it), and made efforts to keep away from the centers of culture, living mostly in provincial [[Sinaia]].<ref name="ln(10)296"/>
Zarifopol, sometimes using the pen names ''PZ'' and ''Anton Gherman'',<ref>Mihail Straje, ''Dicționar de pseudonime, anonime, anagrame, astronime, criptonime ale scriitorilor și publiciștilor români'', p. 805. Bucharest: [[Editura Minerva]], 1973. {{OCLC|8994172}}</ref> returned as one of the main columnists at ''Viața Românească'' and its satellite, ''[[Adevărul Literar și Artistic]]''. Despite his material difficulties, Zarifopol categorically refused Ibrăileanu and [[Petre Andrei]]'s offers to take a professorate at Iași. In early 1920, he complained that the "endless infirmities of my children, my wife, and myself" prevented him from publishing his cultural journalism as an academic volume, which would have qualified him for the office.<ref name="ln(10)296"/> In 1924, Zarifopol informed his protectors that he now had "a holy terror of officialdom", and that he resented Iași for its support for the [[National-Christian Defense League]], a form of "nationalist imbecility and charlatanry". As he noted: "all things considered, I can make a living from journalism alone."<ref>Nastasă (2010), p. 375</ref>
A guest writer at [[Camil Petrescu]]'s ''Săptămâna Intelectuală și Artistică'' in 1924,<ref>Sdrobiș, p. 311</ref> and, in 1925, at ''[[Cuvântul Liber (1924)|Cuvântul Liber]]'',<ref>Lovinescu (1926), p. 276</ref> Zarifopol became more deeply involved in the cultural debates of [[Greater Romania]]. This was the time of his explicit emancipation from Dobrogeanu-Gherea's left-wing [[didacticism]] and from Ibrăileanu's [[Poporanism]]. Didactic and social art, Zarifopol contended, had no real artistic value, and politics were irrelevant in assessing the quality of artistic endeavor. Revising some of his earlier pronouncements on modernism, he now believed in [[art for art's sake]], illustrated by such qualities as "pleasure", "amusement", "life", "drama", "color", "strange sensibilities", or "childish delirium".<ref>Lovinescu (1926), pp. 273–276</ref> His refusal of didactic art aimed higher, showing up in his celebrated essay on [[Leo Tolstoy|Tolstoy]]'s ''[[The Kreutzer Sonata|Kreutzer Sonata]]''.<ref>Dima, pp. 170–171, 176</ref> Working from Sinaia, Zarifopol translated and prefaced an anthology of fantasy short stories, published in 1924 as ''Vedenii'' ("Visions"). Part of his essays were published as ''Din registrul ideilor gingașe'' ("A Register of Tender Ideas", 1926), ''Despre stil'' ("On Style", 1928), ''Artiști și idei literare române'' ("Artists and Ideas in Romanian Literature", 1930), and ''Încercări de precizie literară'' ("Essays in Literary Precision", 1931).<ref name="sasu"/><ref>Călinescu, p. 1025; Grinea Mironescu, p. 8</ref>
Zarifopol's dissidence was admonished by other ''Viața Românească'' veterans Ibrăileanu and [[Mihai Ralea]]. Ibrăileanu took in some of Zarifopol's criticism, but argued that some of Poporanism's theories were rehabilitated in [[psychologism]] or [[social determinism]], without which "an artwork can never hope to be fully understood".<ref>Crohmălniceanu, pp. 141–142</ref> The magazine's literary columnists even accused Zarifopol of committing a "crime" against taste at ''Adevărul Literar și Artistic'', where Zarifopol was introducing [[Aestheticism|aestheticist]] guidelines, albeit with contributions that remained "interesting and profound".<ref>Crohmălniceanu, p. 135</ref> Nonetheless, Zarifopol's derision of traditionalism and [[mysticism]] showed lasting similarities with Ralea's philosophical stances. In 1928, Ralea, Zarifopol, [[D. I. Suchianu]], [[Felix Aderca]] and other literati were lumped together as the "irresponsible malcontents", in a neotraditionalist pamphlet put out by [[Petre Pandrea]] and ''[[Gândirea]]'' magazine.<ref>Crohmălniceanu, p. 89</ref>
In his replies, Zarifopol noted that he did not reject mysticism as a cultural phenomenon, only objecting to the "career mysticism" of traditionalist ideologues.<ref>[[Z. Ornea]], ''Anii treizeci. Extrema dreaptă românească'', p. 77. Bucharest: [[Editura Fundației Culturale Române]], 1995. {{ISBN|973-9155-43-X}}</ref> Contested by young and old critics alike, Zarifopol found himself a follower with [[Mihail Sebastian]], who honored him as "a lucid man in a time of visionaries", "a sober teetotaler during a raging drinking bout".<ref>{{ro icon}} Diana Pîrvan-Jenaru, [http://www.observatorcultural.ro/Mihail-Sebastian-si-arta-de-a-polemiza*articleID_18475-articles_details.html "Mihail Sebastian și arta de a polemiza"], in ''[[Observator Cultural]]'', Nr. 393, October 2007</ref> Zarifopol's cultural role, Sebastian wrote, was that of a "policeman", a "reactionary", who would curb the excesses of mysticism, ''[[Trăirism]]'', and nationalism.<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Ioan Stanomir]], [http://www.revista22.ro/bucurestiul-cultural-nr-12008-4231.html "Semne pe un dulap cu cărți"], in ''[[Revista 22]]'', Nr. 931, January 2008</ref>
===Final creative period and death=== Zarifopol eventually moved to [[Bucharest]] in 1928,<ref name="sasu"/> taking up residence on Strada Spătarului, [[Moșilor]].<ref>Lazu, pp. 82, 328</ref> Slowly discarding social and literary criticism in favor of philology,<ref name="pcon264">Constantinescu, p. 264</ref> he worked on a critical edition of Caragiale's works; he put out the first three volumes (1930, 1931, 1932), winning a prize from the [[Romanian Writers' Society]].<ref name="sasu"/> In March 1929, together with [[Gala Galaction]], [[Nicolae L. Lupu]] and others, he put out the monthly magazine ''Hanul Samariteanului'', which only published a single issue.<ref>Desa ''et al.'', p. 491</ref> Later that year, he became a writer for [[Isac Ludo]]'s mainly Jewish review, ''Adam'',<ref>Camelia Crăciun, "Presa culturală evreiască din România în timpul Holocaustului: cazul revistei ''Adam''", in Anca Ciuciu, Camelia Crăciun (eds.), ''Istorie și memorie evreiască. Volum omagial dedicat doamnei Dr. Lya Benjamin'', p. 140. Bucharest: [[Editura Hasefer]], 2011. {{ISBN|978-973-630-228-2}}. See also Crohmălniceanu, p. 345; Desa ''et al.'', p. 17</ref> and, in ''Viața Românească'', published his review of [[Immanuel Kant]]'s [[aesthetics]] (''Kant și estetica'').<ref>Dima, p. 171</ref> His other contributions appeared in various new magazines and newspapers, including ''[[Adevărul]]'' (which in 1927 hosted his humorous memoir of a meeting with Radek),<ref name="vtstilist"/> ''[[Dreptatea]]'', ''[[Kalende]]'', ''[[Lamura (magazine)|Lamura]]'', ''Gazeta Fălticenilor'', and ''Ancheta''.<ref>Desa ''et al.'', pp. 38–39, 330, 433, 557, 571</ref>
He carried on with his lampoons of traditionalism, publishing, in 1932, an especially mordant portrait of historian [[Vasile Pârvan]], ''Plicticoase fantome'' ("Tedious Apparitions").<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Alexandru George]], [http://www.revistaluceafarul.ro/index.html?id=1228&editie=59 "Cu cât pierdem un mit..."], in ''[[Luceafărul (magazine)|Luceafărul]]'', Nr. 18/2009</ref> He was also involved with ''[[Criterion (literary society)|Criterion]]'', a debate club for political and cultural factions, one of the "old men" who were called upon as both arbiters and active participants. He and Ralea were thus present when the debates about Gide, [[Vladimir Lenin|Lenin]], [[Sigmund Freud]], and [[Charlie Chaplin]] either degenerated into squabbles or were broken up by the far-right Defense League.<ref name="imcrit">{{ro icon}} Irina Manea, [http://www.historia.ro/exclusiv_web/general/articol/criterion-o-istorie "Criterion – o istorie"], in ''Historia'', May 2014</ref>
In 1933, Zarifopol was named editor-in-chief of ''[[Revista Fundațiilor Regale]]'',<ref name="sasu"/><ref name="agm8">Grinea Mironescu, p. 8</ref> the official literary magazine, which was largely conceived by him.<ref name="ovsc171">Crohmălniceanu, p. 171</ref> In February 1934, he was involved with ''[[Convorbiri Literare]]'' in round-table talks that were supposed to revive ''Criterion''.<ref name="imcrit"/> These projects ended abruptly when Zarifopol died of a heart attack on May 1, at 12 AM,<ref name="gc909">Călinescu, p. 909</ref> allegedly while visiting his mistress, musicologist Lisette Georgescu.<ref>[[Mihail Sebastian]], ''Journal, 1935-1944''. London: [[Random House]], 2003, p. 59. {{ISBN|0-7126-8388-7}}</ref> His body was [[Cremation in Romania|cremated]] on May 3,<ref>Nastasă (2010), p. 475</ref> with Camil Petrescu succeeding him at ''Revista Fundațiilor Regale''.<ref name="ovsc171"/>
His most important work as a literary critic appeared posthumously in 1934; called ''Pentru arta literară'' ("For Literary Art"), it was praised by Sebastian as "a model of precise understanding of values and of their order".<ref name="sasu"/> In 1935, [[Șerban Cioculescu]] put out a critical edition of the Caragiale–Zarifopol correspondence, while editing new volumes from the Caragiale corpus, which Zarifopol had begun publishing.<ref>Constantinescu, pp. 239, 269–270, 277. See also Călinescu, p. 1001; Iosifescu, p. 360</ref>
==Work== ===Generic traits=== Once settled in his role as [[art for art's sake]] advocate, Zarifopol created himself a confrontational niche, earning both respect and bewilderment from his readers. A traditionalist adversary, [[Nicolae Iorga]], recognized Zarifopol as a "refined and daring thinker",<ref>Iorga, p. 212</ref> while his ''Viața Românească'' partner Ralea called him "charming and irritating".<ref>Ralea, p. 171</ref> Ralea identified in him "a freethinker" with "the courage of looking truth in the face", but essentially a "freezing intelligence" of "destructive anarchism", a man "alone within his sarcasm".<ref>Ralea, pp. 162–164</ref> A more virulent review came from classicist [[George Călinescu]], who proposed that Zarifopol's one original note was "continuous and systematic persiflage, to the point of annoyance". He attributed such traits to Zarifopol's familiarity with "two sophistic races", Greeks and Jews,<ref name="gc909"/> his claim in turn criticized by Ralea<ref>[[Lucian Boia]], ''Capcanele istoriei. Elita intelectuală românească între 1930 și 1950''. Bucharest: [[Humanitas publishing house|Humanitas]], 2012, p. 243. {{ISBN|978-973-50-3533-4}}</ref> and philosopher [[Mircea Florian]]<ref>Florian, p. 169</ref> for its racialist undertones. Florian also discussed the constructive side of Zarifopol's work, arguing that accusations of "bourgeois anarchism" and "iconoclasm" were prejudiced.<ref>Florian, pp. 169, 170</ref> Another sympathetic reviewer, Andreea Grinea Mironescu, sees Călinescu's pronouncements as "minimizing and petty."<ref name="agm8"/>
[[Eugen Lovinescu]], the modernist literary theorist, shared Zarifopol's overall aesthetic goals, but not his methods: Zarifopol, he writes, was an unlikely follower of [[Titu Maiorescu]]'s non-didactic school of "aesthetic autonomy" and authenticity, which had emerged at ''[[Junimea]]'' in the 1860s, and had also influenced Caragiale.<ref>Lovinescu (1943), pp. 289, 291</ref> In 1941, [[Nicolae Bagdasar]] identified in Zarifopol "a vastly cultured critic, of a rare subtlety and fine irony", lamenting that his work "remains scattered in so many magazines".<ref>[[Nicolae Bagdasar]], "Estetica", in Nicolae Bagdasar, [[Traian Herseni]], S. S. Bârsănescu (eds.), ''Istoria filosofiei moderne, V. Filosofia românească dela origini până astăzi'', p. 253. Bucharest: Romanian Philosophical Society, 1941</ref> However, as argued by colleague [[Pompiliu Constantinescu]], this improvidence was a fundamental trait and shortcoming of Zarifopol's literary contribution: his was a "newspaperman's critique" of "spontaneous impression, quick analysis, and incomplete assessment, meaning that he could never embrace a creator in all their complexity."<ref name="pcon264"/> The same was noted by Călinescu, who argues that Zarifopol's "journalistic method" relied on explicit [[Argumentum ad populum|appeals to popularity]] and [[False precision|spurious accuracy]].<ref>Călinescu, pp. 910–911</ref>
Lovinescu assessed that Zarifopol's criticism "lingers in the paradox", always placing itself "at the antipodes of common sense": denying merit to prestigious figures such as [[Ernest Renan|Renan]] or [[Guy de Maupassant|Maupassant]], but praising [[Ion Minulescu]] as an outstanding novelist. His "practical" verdicts, Lovinescu notes, remain "disoriented", "regrettable".<ref name="el(26)272–3">Lovinescu (1926), pp. 272–273</ref> He acknowledges Zarifopol's "stylistic rigor", but concludes that his is "an equation in which the unknown is better left unknown",<ref>Lovinescu (1926), pp. 276–277</ref> something "virtually alien to the rhythms of our literary movement."<ref>Lovinescu (1943), p. 289</ref> The same was argued decades later by Lovinescu disciple [[Nicolae Manolescu]].<ref>Grinea Mironescu, pp. 8, 9</ref>
According to Ralea, Zarifopol should be read as a Romanian counterpart of anti-populist "lone travelers", from [[Jules Amédée Barbey d'Aurevilly|Barbey d'Aurevilly]] and [[Edgar Allan Poe]] to [[Hanns Heinz Ewers]], often applauding causes that were "at odds with the establishment".<ref>Ralea, pp. 159–161</ref> Thus, responding to the established literary canons, Zarifopol fashioned himself an alternative one, comprising Caragiale, Minulescu, Proust and Cocteau, but also [[Joseph Delteil]], [[Henri de Régnier]], [[Adrian Maniu]], [[Păstorel Teodoreanu]],<ref>Lovinescu (1926), pp. 275–276. See also Balotă, p. 215; Grinea Mironescu, p. 9; Zalis, pp. 8–9</ref> and [[Dragoș Protopopescu]].<ref>Crohmălniceanu, p. 376</ref> Călinescu believes that Zarifopol was most "intelligent" in his essays on Proust and [[Gustave Flaubert]], where he overcame his usual "journalistic banality".<ref>Călinescu, p. 911</ref>
===Aesthetic ideals=== Zarifopol's rejection of [[neoclassicism]], from [[Johann Wolfgang von Goethe|Goethe]] to [[Dimitrie Bolintineanu]], but also his friend [[Panait Cerna]], had to do with both its "mechanic" use of poetic imagery and its communication of "bland truths".<ref>Balotă, pp. 215–218, 222–223</ref> He preferred archaic Moldavian forms, that he found resonating in the poetry of [[Dosoftei]] and [[Vasile Alecsandri]].<ref>Zalis, pp. 7, 8</ref> Călinescu was especially critical of Zarifopol literal and "negativist" reading of [[Alexandru Vlahuță]]'s ''Din prag'', which ridiculed the poet's presentment of death eternal.<ref>Călinescu, pp. 909–910</ref>
Such a sustained attack, equated by comparatist [[Nicolae Balotă]] with "a holocaust of poetry",<ref>Balotă, p. 223</ref> nevertheless impressed Lovinescu. The latter declared himself in agreement with the thesis that ancient models were perishable, and that traditionalist art was implicitly false.<ref>Lovinescu (1926), p. 273; (1943), pp. 290–291</ref> Seen by [[Alexandru Paleologu]] as a more radical anti-classicist than Zarifopol ever was,<ref>Grinea Mironescu, p. 9</ref> Lovinescu noted in 1943: "as modernism or synchronism, I have been supporting those same ideas these past twenty years."<ref>Lovinescu (1943), p. 291</ref> Zarifopol's revolt was more contextual, and bound by his own debt to the classics: Ralea sees him as a classical [[Rationalism|rationalist]] in the manner of [[Voltaire]], [[Charles Augustin Sainte-Beuve|Sainte-Beuve]], and [[Anatole France]],<ref>Ralea, pp. 162, 168, 170</ref> and Călinescu as a "cultured academic, for all his freethinking airs", copying his style from Caragiale and [[Tudor Arghezi]], without "a sense of the sublime".<ref>Călinescu, pp. 909, 910</ref> Balotă also finds Zarifopol a "suppressed scholar", "in denial of his formative background".<ref>Balotă, p. 214</ref>
Călinescu sees Zarifopol a man of little classical culture, his "obviously German method" being more akin to the [[sociology of literature]].<ref name="gc909"/> Such verdicts were nuanced by another literary historian, [[Alexandru Dima]], who suggests that Zarifopol did have contribution to the scholarly study of [[aesthetics]], one which "imposes itself even against his own wish."<ref>Dima, p. 170</ref> Zarifopol's rejection of [[scientism]] and [[historicism]] had deep roots in ''Junimism'' and [[Neo-Kantianism]], but Zarifopol also criticized Kantian [[Observations on the Feeling of the Beautiful and Sublime|assumptions about the sublime]], finding them too indebted to ethical imperatives.<ref>Dima, pp. 171–175; Lovinescu (1943), p. 289</ref> As noted by Dima, his attachment to [[Phenomenology (philosophy)|phenomenology]] was "at the very least formal".<ref>Dima, p. 175</ref> According to Balotă, his applications of the art for art's sake principle show that, despite his own claims to the contrary, Zarifopol borrowed his [[poetics]] from [[Henri Brémond]], [[Paul Valéry]], and [[Stéphane Mallarmé]].<ref>Balotă, pp. 218–221</ref>
===Social critic=== Revisiting Zarifopol's moralizing essays in 2007, critic [[Henri Zalis]] found him to be "chaste and meticulous, and in this unmatched."<ref>Zalis, p. 6</ref> ''Din registrul ideilor gingașe'', is, according to Lovinescu, an "interesting intellectual spectacle of deliberate originality".<ref name="el(26)272–3"/> This is one of several essays containing Zarifopol's ''Junimea''-like satire of inauthentic ''mofturi'' ("trifles" or "coquetries", a term echoing Caragiale), including wholesale borrowings of foreign customs that respond to bourgeois tastes.<ref>Călinescu, p. 909; Lovinescu (1943), pp. 290–292; Ralea, pp. 160–161, 167–171</ref> The eponymous "tender ideas" were defined by Zarifopol as "those which should be familiar to any man wishing to pass for cultured, and also those that said man must be careful to speak about just so, lest he insult the views of society"; the book was addressed to those skeptics who, rejecting cultural crazes, "still value consistency".<ref name="cmsging">{{ro icon}} [[Cassian Maria Spiridon]], [http://convorbiri-literare.dntis.ro/TATAmar13.htm "Ideile gingașe și actualitatea lor contondentă"], in ''[[Convorbiri Literare]]'', March 2013</ref> As Ralea notes, Zarifopol's anti-ideological critique, continuing the work of Caragiale, was specifically deriding philosophers and philosophies that were the height of fashion: mystical, [[Henri Bergson|Bergsonian]], [[Japonism|Japonist]];<ref>Ralea, pp. 161, 167–168, 170–171</ref> other such hobbyhorses were [[Philosophy of Friedrich Nietzsche|Nietzscheism]]<ref name="cmsging"/> and [[psychoanalysis]].<ref name="gc909"/>
Călinescu was unimpressed by Zarifopol's "rather belated" satire of bourgeois mores, since "the bourgeois is no longer that ridiculous conservative figure".<ref name="gc909"/> Yet, Zarifopol was not entirely anti-middle class: he believed his type of "cold lucidity" was primarily an in-built antidote to the decay of the "colossal civilization" that was liberal society.<ref>Florian, pp. 170–171; Ralea, p. 170</ref> He issued what Florian calls a "passionate call to order of the bourgeoisie, [which is] still a bearer of cultural values."<ref>Florian, p. 170</ref> Himself a conservative, Zarifopol expressed his nostalgia for old-regime [[Differentiation (sociology)|social differentiation]] and [[division of labor]], against "the political type", and for the [[nuclear family]] of [[patriarchy]], against the "neutralization" of fathers in modern society. He criticizes both [[Francophilia]] and [[Germanophilia]], noting that, although competing, they each supported [[deindividuation]]: the former, through [[corporatism]]; the latter, through [[militarism]].<ref name="cmsging"/> While targeting [[philistinism]], ''Din registrul...'' is itself an [[Anti-intellectualism|antiintellectualist]] manifesto. Zarifopol contended that intellectuals were an illusory social class (no economic interest bound together "a lawyer with a novelist"), but still collectively responsible for the failures of a society such as Romania's.<ref>Sdrobiș, pp. 312–313</ref>
Zarifopol took distance from more radical antiintelectualist stances, communist as well as Christian; but also noted that natural disunity between intellectuals meant that [[communist terrorism]] was itself an intellectuals' affair.<ref name="cmsging"/><ref>Sdrobiș, pp. 313–314</ref> Both ''Din registrul...'' an other writings show him as an [[anti-Soviet]] in line with [[Nikolai Berdyaev]], and believed that [[Leninism]] was a somewhat worrisome, but generally puerile, non-philosophy.<ref name="vtstilist"/> Like [[fascism]] and, historically, [[Bonapartism]], it stood for a "simplistic autocratic drive" and "stupefied blindness". Moreover, Zarifopol rejected [[Marxist literary criticism]], with its discourse of [[base and superstructure]], seeing it as the source of modernist kitsch.<ref name="cmsging"/>
In 2014, posthumously reviewing Zarifiopol's anticommunist notes, scholar [[Vladimir Tismăneanu]] described him as a diagnostician of "totalitarian reflexes", displaying "urbanity, civility, moderation and firmness".<ref name="vtstilist"/> Evidence also exists that, beyond this public persona, Zarifopol was more illiberal. Prolonging his [[Antihumanism|antihumanist]] tendencies,<ref>Ralea, p. 170</ref> he expressed in private his reserves for the "deplorable" literature of "the oppressed", including Jews, social climbers, and especially women; according to Nastasă, he was an [[Antifeminism|antifeminist]], and perhaps also a misogynist.<ref>Nastasă (2010), pp. 49–50</ref> In 1932, writer [[Barbu Brezianu]] suggested that Zarifopol was on the "far-right" of Romanian literature, in the "grand conservative party" of [[D. Nanu]], [[Cincinat Pavelescu]], [[Mihail Sadoveanu]], and [[Al. T. Stamatiad]].<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Barbu Brezianu]], [http://convorbiri-literare.dntis.ro/BREZIANUfeb8.html "Curs de literatură politică"], in ''[[Convorbiri Literare]]'', February 2008</ref>
==Legacy== Fany Zarifopol, born in 1876, lived until 1945. Paul Jr spent seventeen years as a political prisoner under the [[Communist Romania|communist regime]],<ref name="s407"/> being released with a general amnesty in 1964.<ref name="vtstilist"/> Officially designating him a "bourgeois idealist",<ref>S. Mureșeanu, "Recenzii. ''Istoria gîndirii sociale și filozofice în România''", in ''Studii. Revistă de Istorie'', Nr. 1/1965, p. 201</ref> [[Censorship in Communist Romania|communist censorship]] prevented Zarifopol's essays from being either reprinted or quoted before the mid 1960s liberalization. When they were finally returned to circulation, large parts of his work were still being bracketed out.<ref>[[Monica Lovinescu]], ''Unde scurte'', p. 146. Bucharest: [[Humanitas publishing house|Humanitas]], 1990. {{ISBN|973-28-0172-7}}; Grinea Mironescu, p. 8</ref>
Sonia Zarifopol, who never married,<ref name="s407"/> was a lover of literature and, in the 1930s, a discreet presence at Lovinescu's ''[[Sburătorul]]'' society.<ref>{{ro icon}} Bianca Burța-Cernat, [http://www.revistaluceafarul.ro/index.html?id=2963&editie=127 "''Sburătorul'': fotografie de grup cu scriitoare uitate"], in ''[[Luceafărul (magazine)|Luceafărul]]'', Nr. 3/2011</ref> She kept her father's entire collection of manuscripts and documents, now housed at the [[Museum of Romanian Literature]]. She died in 1981, and her brother three years later; neither had children of their own.<ref name="s407"/> George Zarifopol's son,<ref name="evmicle"/> Constantin Radu "Dinu", was a published novelist.<ref name="raczibloo">{{ro icon}} Raluca Alexandrescu, Christina Zarifopol-Illias, [http://www.observatorcultural.ro/Bloomington-Indiana-o-activa-ambasada-romaneasca.-Interviu-cu-Christina-ZARIFOPOL-ILLIAS*articleID_5855-articles_details.html "Bloomington, Indiana: o activă ambasadă românească"], in ''[[Observator Cultural]]'', Nr. 19, July 2000</ref> His daughter Ilinca, marginalized at home for her aristocratic descent, emigrated to the United States in 1977. A linguist and comparatist, she taught at [[Indiana University Bloomington]], marrying Anglicist Kenneth R. Johnston.<ref name="izjnote"/> She was joined there by her sister Christina Zarifopol-Illias, who organized the Bloomington Romanian Studies Program.<ref name="raczibloo"/>
The critical reappraisal of Zarifopol, begun by [[Eugen Simion]] in 1956, was taken up in the 1980s by Paleologu and [[Marin Mincu]].<ref>Grinea Mironescu, pp. 8–9</ref> In underground culture, his memory was cultivated by the essayist [[Nicolae Steinhardt]]. Although a fervent Orthodox, he viewed the non-believers Zarifopol and Ralea as intellectual standards, praising their "quick wit".<ref name="esstein"/> From 1971, [[Al. Săndulescu]] was allowed to publish selections of Zarifopol's literary prose,<ref name="agm8"/> and, in 1987, Zarifopol's correspondence (at [[Editura Minerva]], with samples in ''[[Manuscriptum]]'' magazine).<ref>Nastasă (2010), pp. 50, 206, 247, 296, 359, 369, 427</ref> A more thorough recovery came after the [[Romanian Revolution of 1989]], when more complete anthologies first emerged, and Zarifopol monographs were published by [[Alex. Cistelecan]].<ref name="agm8"/> In 1992, his formerly censored critique of socialism was issued by [[Editura Albatros]] as a standalone book, ''Marxism amuzant'' ("Amusing Marxism").<ref name="vtstilist"/> His Bucharest home was not fitted with a memorial plaque—the new owners having reportedly refused to allow it.<ref>Lazu, pp. 163, 237, 328</ref>

The '''Penrith Hoard''' is a dispersed [[hoard]] of 10th century silver [[penannular brooch]]es found at Flusco Pike, Newbiggin Moor, Near [[Penrith, Cumbria|Penrith]] in [[Cumbria]], and now in the [[British Museum]] in London. The largest "thistle brooch" was discovered in 1785 and another in 1830, with the bulk of items being recovered in two groups close to each other by archaeologists in 1989.<ref>{{cite web | title=Silver 'thistle' brooch | publisher=[[British Museum]] | url=https://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/highlights/highlight_objects/pe_mla/s/silver_thistle_brooch.aspx | accessdate=2010-07-14 }}</ref> Whether all the finds made close to each other were originally deposited at the same time remains uncertain, but it is thought likely that at least the brooches were. The brooches are thought to have been deposited in about 930.
==Discoveries== [[File:Brit Mus 17sept 014-crop.jpg|thumb|left|upright|The "brambled" terminal of the largest brooch in the main picture.]] The earliest surviving finds were discovered in what was already called the "Silver Field" on Newbiggin Moor by a small boy in 1785, the name suggesting that earlier finds, now lost, had been made. In 1830 another smaller thistle brooch was found. Although the exact find spot is not known, this brooch is strongly suspected to have also come from the "Silver Field".<ref>[http://www.lancs.ac.uk/depts/cnwrs/papers%20on%20the%20web/arch%20conf%20synopses%201999.rtf Synopses of papers given at the 26th Annual Archaeology Conference, 6 March 1999] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110605231456/http://www.lancs.ac.uk/depts/cnwrs/papers%20on%20the%20web/arch%20conf%20synopses%201999.rtf |date=5 June 2011 }}, University of Lancaster Centre for North-West Regional Studies. Retrieved 6 August 2010.</ref> The usual reason for a hoard being "disbursed" is that routine farming operations like ploughing can move some items of a single hoard before they are discovered.
Later archaeological investigations in 1989 at the same spot revealed other silver items that confirmed that this was a dispersed hoard and not a solitary loss of one brooch. Two groups of items were found in nearby fields: one consisted of five Viking brooches, with fragments of two more, and the other of more than fifty items comprising coins, [[ingot]]s, jewellery and [[hacksilver]] (jewellery and other silver pieces chopped up) of a very similar date.<ref>[https://www.britishmuseum.org/research/search_the_collection_database/search_object_details.aspx?objectid=3242725&partid=1&output=Places%2f!!%2fOR%2f!!%2f30930%2f!%2f30930-3-1%2f!%2fExcavated%2fFindspot+Penrith%2f!%2f%2f!!%2f%2f!!!%2f&orig=%2fresearch%2fsearch_the_collection_database%2fadvanced_search.aspx&currentPage=2&numpages=10 British Museum collection database] "ingot/hacksilver", item from the second hoard.</ref> The brooches were declared to be "[[treasure trove]]" at an inquest held in Penrith on 23 July 1990, and entered the British Museum in 1991, joined by the other hoard in 2009.
==Context== The penannular brooch, originally a common utilitarian clothes fastening, normally of [[base metal]], in [[Roman Britain]] developed in the post-Roman period into highly elaborate and decorative marks of status in Ireland and Scotland, made in precious metals and often decorated with gems, and worn by men and women. When the Vikings began to raid and settle the British Isles, they took to wearing these brooches, but now in plain silver. The thistle and bossed types represented in the hoard were the most popular styles, both developing out of earlier Celtic styles.
It has been speculated that the hoard, with items strongly suggesting an Irish connection, is connected with the events of 927, a date which matches the style of the finds. In that year "the kings of Strathclyde and Scotland came south to Penrith to pay homage to [[Athelstan of England|Athelstan]]". Also in the area with his army was the troublesome [[Norse-Gael]] [[king of Dublin]], [[Gofraid ua Ímair]], or Gothfrith. Athelstan made the kings, who had apparently been associating with pagan Vikings like Gothrith, renounce idolatry, but "Gothfrith and company had slipped away in order to attack [[Viking York|York]]".<ref>Graham-Campbell, 224</ref> After briefly making himself [[king of Northumbria]] there, he was chased out and replaced by Athelstan later in the year, and went back to Ireland. At some point during these manoevres the hoards may have been deposited.
==Items discovered== [[File:Brit Mus 13sept10 brooches etc 040.jpg|thumb|left|Penannular brooch with "gripping beasts" connecting the ring to the terminals, and a [[rune|runic]] [[futhark]] scratched on the reverse of the hoop.]]
The large thistle brooch soon passed to the [[Leverian Museum]], a private museum in [[Leicester Square]] in London. In 1787 a print of it was published, claiming that it was the insignia of the [[Knights Templar]].<ref>[https://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/online_tours/britain/enlightenment_archaeology/silver_thistle_brooch.aspx British Museum] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110213230940/https://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/online_tours/britain/enlightenment_archaeology/silver_thistle_brooch.aspx |date=2011-02-13 }} ''Enlightenment: The Birth of Archaeology, Silver 'thistle' brooch''</ref> It was bought by the British Museum in 1909 (M&ME 1909,6-24,2).<ref>[https://www.britishmuseum.org/research/search_the_collection_database/search_object_details.aspx?objectid=65058&partid=1&searchText=Penrith+Hoard&numpages=10&orig=%2fresearch%2fsearch_the_collection_database.aspx&currentPage=6 British Museum collection database] Large silver brooch (M&ME 1909,6-24,2).</ref>
The brooch discovered in 1830, the largest in the group illustrated, entered the museum in 1904 (M&ME 1904,1102.3). One terminal is missing, and the pin is 52 cm long. In 1989 two further incomplete thistle brooches and pieces from three bossed-type brooches were found, which are seen with the 1830 brooch in the group illustration above. The most complete of the 1989 group (illustrated left) has a [[rune|runic]] [[futhark]] scratched on the reverse of the hoop.<ref>[https://www.britishmuseum.org/research/search_the_collection_database/search_object_details.aspx?objectid=1615235&partid=1&searchText=Penannular+Penrith&numpages=10&orig=%2fresearch%2fsearch_the_collection_database.aspx&currentPage=1 British Museum collection database] brooch (M&ME 1991,0109.2).</ref> The other two have [[interlace (art)|interlace]] around the bosses on the terminals.
It is thought likely that all these brooches were originally deposited together and have been dispersed and damaged by ploughing.

'''Random International''' is a London-based art collective and collaborative studio, founded in 2005. The group shot to prominence with its interactive ''[[Rain Room]]'' art installation. Random International creates art installations that investigate notions of human consciousness, perception and instinct. Its work, which includes sculpture, performance and large-scale architectural installations, reflects the relationship between man and machine and centres on audience interaction.<ref name="Barbican">{{Cite web|url=https://www.barbican.org.uk/rain-room-random-international|title=Rain Room, Random International|website=www.barbican.org.uk|access-date=2018-07-17}}</ref> Two of its exhibition pieces have now become permanent installations, the first of which was the critically acclaimed and popular ''Rain Room'', now permanently housed in [[Sharjah]], [[United Arab Emirates|United Arab Emirates (UAE)]].
The group was founded in 2005 by German artists Hannes Koch and Florian Ortkrass. Ortkrass graduated from the [[Royal College of Art]] in London in 2005, while Koch graduated in 2004. Its relentless experimentation with digital technologies and reflections of the human form has led it to collaborate with [[Harvard University|Harvard]] roboticists on creating 'point studies' that reduce representation of the human form in motion into 15 light points,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.artslant.com/ew/articles/show/43500-random-international-art-technologys-magical-realists|title=Random International: Art & Technology's Magical Realists {{!}} ArtSlant|website=ArtSlant|access-date=2018-11-24}}</ref> as well as with architects to create large scale public displays that include covering a German train station with LED lights.<ref name=":5" />
== Rain Room == ''Rain Room'', now installed in Sharjah, United Arab Emirates, was the first installation of a Random International project in a purpose-built, permanent structure. The work was previously shown at the [[Barbican Centre|Barbican]], London (2012);<ref name="Barbican2">{{Cite web|url=https://www.barbican.org.uk/rain-room-random-international|title=Rain Room, Random International|website=www.barbican.org.uk|access-date=2018-07-17}}</ref> [[Museum of Modern Art|MoMA]], New York (2013); Yuz Museum, Shanghai (2015) and [[Los Angeles County Museum of Art|LACMA]], Los Angeles (2015–2017). ''Rain Room'' allows visitors to the installation to walk through a downpour without getting wet.<ref name="Barbican3">{{Cite web|url=https://www.barbican.org.uk/rain-room-random-international|title=Rain Room, Random International|website=www.barbican.org.uk|access-date=2018-07-17}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://gulfnews.com/news/uae/leisure/rain-room-brings-fun-intrigue-to-sharjah-1.2215470|title=Rain Room brings fun, intrigue to Sharjah|last=Reporter|first=Faisal Masudi, Staff|date=2018-05-02|work=GulfNews|access-date=2018-07-17}}</ref> Motion sensors detect visitors' movements as they navigate through the darkened space, becoming "performers in this intersection of art, technology and nature".<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.sharjahart.org/sharjah-art-foundation/projects/rain-room|title=projects - Sharjah Art Foundation|last=|first=|date=|website=www.sharjahart.org|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-18}}</ref> The work has been a celebrated [[Instagram]] theme:<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.peninsula.com/en/shanghai/our-city/pencities/content-calendar/everything-or-nothing|title=Everything or Nothing {{!}} The Peninsula Shanghai|website=www.peninsula.com|language=en|access-date=2018-11-24}}</ref> the photo and video sharing platform has been cited as a major source of Random International's popular recognition.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.architecturaldigest.com/story/random-international-public-art|title=Random International Is Creating Viral Public Art for the Instagram Age {{!}} Architectural Digest|work=Architectural Digest|access-date=2018-11-24|language=en}}</ref>
In 2015, billionaire [[Budi Tek]], Yuz Museum's founder,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.artnews.com/2018/03/28/lacma-yuz-museum-will-partner-exhibitions-programming/|title=In Historic U.S.-China Partnership, Budi Tek’s Shanghai-Based Yuz Museum Will Partner With LACMA|last=Binlot|first=Ann|date=2018-03-28|website=ARTnews|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-24}}</ref> announced he would build a 150 square metre ''Rain Room'' in [[Bali]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/xy4gjj/rain-room-in-the-rain-forest-billionaire-plans-bali-art-theme-park|title=Rain Room in the Rain Forest: Billionaire Plans Bali Art Theme Park|date=2015-03-13|work=Vice|access-date=2018-11-24|language=en-us}}</ref> The plan was shelved due to Tek's ill-health.
A number of Chinese companies have copied the ''Rain Room'' concept and, in 2016, the Chinese Jiajiale Dream Park opened its $15 million ''Rain Room'' clone called the ''Magic Rain Zone''. One company offers as many as 12 clones of the installation. Koch estimated that as many as 8-10 companies had produced ''Rain Room'' clones.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/vv5xyb/rent-your-own-rain-rooms-become-big-business-in-china|title=Rent-Your-Own Rain Rooms Become Big Business in China|date=2017-05-16|work=Vice|access-date=2018-11-24|language=en-us}}</ref>
== Instant Structure for Schacht XII == The group's first outdoor installation was ''Tower: Instant Structure for Schacht XII,''<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.designboom.com/art/random-international-build-towering-shower-at-ruhrtriennale/|title=random international builds towering shower at ruhrtriennale|date=2013-09-03|work=designboom {{!}} architecture & design magazine|access-date=2018-11-24|language=en-US}}</ref> created for [[Urbane Künste Ruhr]] for the [[Ruhrtriennale]] 2013. The work cycled 30,000 litres of water per minute from the former coal mines of [[Zollverein Coal Mine Industrial Complex|Zollverin]], a World Heritage site, to create an instantaneous towering structure of water. The mines pump millions of water out each year to maintain the surrounding area's structural integrity.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/mgpqpn/random-international-tower-instant-structure-for-schacht-XII|title=Random International Turn 30,000 Liters Of Water Into A Monumental Tower|date=2013-09-05|work=Vice|access-date=2018-11-24|language=en-us}}</ref>
== Self & Other == The first permanent installation in the UK for Random International, ''Self & Other,'' is located on the [[South Bank]] arts and cultural area of the [[Albert Embankment]]. It was launched in July 2018.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.itsnicethat.com/news/random-international-sculpture-art-270618|title=Random International is unveiling their first UK permanent kinetic sculpture|date=2018-06-27|work=It’s Nice That|access-date=2018-11-24}}</ref>
== Swarm Studies == A series of works based on LED walls that mimic the flocking behavior of birds, fish, and insects, Random International's ''Swarm Studies'' have been created ranging from a small version, ''Swarm Study / XI,'' at the Park Hyatt New York’s restaurant Bevy, to the huge ''Swarm Study / IX'', which spans the entire façade of the train station in [[Chemnitz]], Germany—the group's largest installation at the time.<ref name=":5">{{Cite news|url=https://www.architecturaldigest.com/story/random-international-public-art|title=Random International Is Creating Viral Public Art for the Instagram Age {{!}} Architectural Digest|work=Architectural Digest|access-date=2018-11-24|language=en}}</ref> The first of these studies, 2010's ''Swarm Light'' is in the collection of the Maxine & Stuart Frankel Foundation For Art in Michigan.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://archello.com/project/swarm-light|title=SWARM LIGHT {{!}} Random International {{!}} Archello|website=Archello|language=en|access-date=2018-11-24}}</ref> Commissioned by London's [[Victoria and Albert Museum|V&A]], ''Swarm Study / III'' consists of four cubic forms suspended from the ceiling, each made of a grid of illuminated brass rods. A camera tracks visitors, making the lights of the installation flicker, brighten, and dim in response to their movements.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.designboom.com/art/random-international-swarm-studyiii-at-the-va/|title=random international: swarm study/iii at the V&A|date=2011-07-02|work=designboom {{!}} architecture & design magazine|access-date=2018-11-24|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Everything & Nothing == The group's first [[solo exhibition]] in Asia, ''Everything & Nothing'', was on display at Shanghai's Yuz Museum from 20 April – 2 September 2018. The exhibition takes its title from the video installation, ''Everything & Nothing'' (2016), which attempts to question humankind’s place in a technological dynamic by showing a steamroller crushing everything in its path.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://news.artnet.com/exhibitions/rain-room-sharjah-uae-1275371|title=Random International’s Rain Room Gets Its First Permanent Home—in the Desert {{!}} artnet News|date=2018-04-30|work=artnet News|access-date=2018-11-24|language=en-US}}</ref> ''Everything & Nothing'' is the collective's first work to be created from video alone, a loop of over 6 hours. The piece was originally commissioned for the ''Wonder Materials'' exhibition at the [[Science and Industry Museum|Manchester Museum of Science and Industry]], where it was displayed in 2016.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://www.random-international.com/everything-and-nothing-2016/|title=RANDOM INTERNATIONAL|website=RANDOM INTERNATIONAL|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-24}}</ref>
''Everything & Nothing'' "documents the simultaneous decay and progress of the industrialised world in an age of relentless transformation." <ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.yuzmshanghai.org/random-international-everything-nothing/|title=Random International: Everything & Nothing - Yuz Museum Shanghai|work=Yuz Museum Shanghai|access-date=2018-11-24|language=en-US}}</ref> The collective's newest work at the time of the exhibition was also displayed, ''Turnstiles'' (2018), an analogue piece which consists of a maze of barriers. ''Self & Other'', another exhibit, consists of a reflective wall of mirrors, light and glass which reflect the visitor taking a selfie.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=http://www.timeoutshanghai.com/event/Art-Art_Exhibitions/53866/Everything--Nothing.html|title=Everything & Nothing|last=|first=|date=24 November 2018|website=Time Out Shanghai|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> The exhibition also saw ''Rain Room'' return to the museum in a revised and larger format, 1,600 square feet (larger, in fact, than the Sharjah installation).<ref name=":2" /> ''[[Time Out (magazine)|Time Out]]'' Shanghai reviewed the exhibition saying, "''Everything & Nothing'' is a meditative video installation about how fucked we are in this age of un-tempered technological advancement. 'Turnstiles' tracks the same story, but instead with a matrix of spinny turnstiles that you can navigate while doing your best to avoid serious injury to the groin area."<ref name=":4" />
== Previous works == The group has previously held solo exhibitions at Lunds Konsthall, Sweden (2014),<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.pacegallery.com/artists/702/random-international|title=Pace Gallery - Random International|work=Pace Gallery|access-date=2018-11-24}}</ref> Carpenters Workshop Gallery, Paris (2012),<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.designboom.com/art/random-international-self-portrait-temporary-printing-machine/|title=random international's self portrait temporary printing machine|date=2012-09-27|work=designboom {{!}} architecture & design magazine|access-date=2018-11-24|language=en-US}}</ref> and [[Pace Gallery]], New York (2016).<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/z4qan9/random-international-exhibition-rain-room|title=The 'Rain Room' Creators Are Getting Their Own Exhibition|date=2016-08-24|work=Vice|access-date=2018-11-24|language=en-us}}</ref> Its work is held in the collections of MoMA, [[Sharjah Art Foundation]], Yuz Museum, LACMA and London's V&A, where its ''Swarm Study / III'' is on long-term display.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.pacegallery.com/artists/702/random-international|title=Pace Gallery - Random International|work=Pace Gallery|access-date=2018-11-24}}</ref>
In 2017, its work ''Zoological'' debuted at London’s [[Roundhouse (venue)|Roundhouse]] as part of Wayne McGregor’s ''+/- Human''. The group's work has also formed part of the Lichtsicht Biennale (2015), Ruhrtriennale (2013), and [[Moscow Biennale|Moscow Biennale of Contemporary Ar]]<nowiki/>t (2011).<ref name=":3" />
